p: Interestingly, based on an extended in silico analysis of the dominant Haemophilus-level-classified OTUs detected in this study (> 0.01% average relative abundance, n = 10), we conclude that Haemophilus data described in this study predominantly belongs to the species of Haemophilus influenza (Additional file 2: Figure S7) . The top 10 most abundant Haemophilus-classified OTUs together comprise 99.65% of the reads belonging to all 361 detected Haemophilus genus OTUs (Additional file 5: Table S4). Of these 10 OTUs, one could confidently be assigned to H. parainfluenzae and comprise 0.25% of all reads in this study, and two other OTUs were assigned to an unknown cluster (0.31%). The remaining seven OTUs, the major fraction of Haemophilus-assigned reads, could confidently be assigned to H. influenza (27.7% of all reads in this study). Other candidate taxa involved in the RDA separation, such as Achromobacter, Veillonella, and Leptotrichia were not highly abundant in the overall microbiome and did not correlate with disease severity (Additional file 2: Figure S4). In conclusion, RSV is marked by a strong increase in Haemophilus and to lesser extent Achromobacter, but RSV disease severity cannot be related to microbiota composition.
